Fractional scaling support

note.body:
Not sure where is the best place to express my opinion, so I will leave it here, because Google has led me here when I was looking for "gnome 3 fractional scaling" :smiley: .

I almost completely agree with [this comment](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gnome-shell/merge_requests/5#note_360311) from @parrenin, except for one think with I find important for me (and maybe many others).

It is hard to work long time on 14" laptop screen with 1920x1080 resolution without any scaling. It is really not pleasant for eyes. I would really love to be able to scale for about 1.2-1.4 (not sure which one would be best) for this size of the display and this resolution.

I honestly wonder how people find 1920x1080 resolution on a 14" (or even 13", and maybe 15") without scaling pleasant. I happen to a also have a 13" MacBookPro, and I noticed that despite the a smaller portion of information (compared to 1920x1080 on 13") which can be present on its screen with its default (fine tuned) settings, I really like it more because my my eyes don't strain.

I would love to have the possibility to use different scaling e.g. 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5. 

PS: I have a friend who recently switched from Dell XPS 13 (Ubuntu) to MacBook Pro 13" because "the info on the screen was too small to pleasantly work on the laptop".

Hope my feedback was useful.
Thank you very much for your effort and work.

Revert to old address bar behaviour in Nautilus
Revert to old address bar behaviour in Nautilus

note.body:
Regarding the alignment, I believe when the window is bigger than a certain threshold, it would be aesthetically much more pleasing to have the path bar's alignment bound to the separator between the side pane and the main pane, like it's marked in this screenshot.
![Screenshot_from_2019-04-26_14-55-23](/uploads/39e3ea35c53c2d3128375e01099b4d18/Screenshot_from_2019-04-26_14-55-23.png)

Regarding the pathbar behaviour, yes, the previous versions of Nautilus did make current directory look like a pressed button, which would prevent users from opening context menu. However, opening context menu in current directory is much easier by right clicking anywhere on the main pane, rather than right clicking on the pathbar. However, if the current change seems to be a step in the right direction, then my suggestion would be to allow an option to switch back to the old behavior, because I think the convenience of going up and down a branch of sub-directories far outweigh the right contextual menu in pathbar.

Please allow custom shortcuts (especially for custom scripts)

note.body:
As explained further when following the link from the first post, to replace keyboard shortcuts with self defined shortcuts for functions like Rename, open, etc., the so called "Python bindings for the Nautilus extension framework" is used. With this we can easily change the functionality of shortcut keys to other functionality.

Install python-nautilus with:
```
sudo apt-get install python-nautilus
```

Then to create a shortcut to Rename with the Enter key and opening a file/directory with <Alt>Down, we create the following file:
```
mkdir -p $HOME/.local/share/nautilus-python/extensions/
cat << EOF > $HOME/.local/share/nautilus-python/extensions/osx_keybindings.py
#!/usr/bin/env python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
#
# by Marc Nijdam, 2018-Dec
# dev201842@auditeon.com
#
 
import os, gi
gi.require_version('Nautilus', '3.0')
from gi.repository import GObject, Nautilus, Gtk, Gio, GLib
 
def ok():
    app = Gtk.Application.get_default()
    # Search for open_accels and nautilus_application_set_accelerators in:
    #   https://github.com/GNOME/nautilus/blob/master/src/nautilus-files-view.c
    app.set_accels_for_action( "view.rename", ["Return", "KP_Enter", "<Primary>Return"] )
    app.set_accels_for_action( "view.open-with-default-application", ["<alt>Down", "<control>o"] )
 
 
class BackspaceBack(GObject.GObject, Nautilus.LocationWidgetProvider):
    def __init__(self):
        pass
 
    def get_widget(self, uri, window):
        ok()
        return None
EOF
```

With the following commands it is for example possible to find what action as mapped to which shortcut:
```
print "1. " , app.get_actions_for_accel("<alt>Up")
print "2. " , app.get_actions_for_accel("<alt>Down")
print "3. " , app.get_actions_for_accel("F2")
print "4.1. " , app.get_actions_for_accel("Return")
print "4.2. " , app.get_actions_for_accel("KP_Enter")
print "4.3. " , app.get_actions_for_accel("<control>o")
print "4.4. " , app.get_actions_for_accel("<alt>Down")
print "4.5. " , app.get_actions_for_accel("<Primary>Return")
```

When done, restart nautilus with:
```
killall nautilus
```

Then, when calling nautilus from the command shell, there may appear one or more warnings:
  * ```Nautilus-Share-Message: Called “net usershare info” but it failed```
  * ```sys:1: PyGIWarning: Nautilus was imported without specifying a version first. Use gi.require_version('Nautilus', '3.0') before import to ensure that the right version gets loaded.```

The first can be solved by install smbclient and/or creating /var/lib/samba/usershares/ as in:
```
sudo mkdir -p /var/lib/samba/usershares/
sudo apt-get install smbclient
```

The second looks like a bug, but might be solved by a try/except/else statement using the warning module. This code seems to do exactly what the warning output recommends though.

events.target_title: flatpak: provide 32-bit compat extensions for the platform

note.body:
`.Sdk.Compat.` extensions are indeed needed, too.
I've used this elements to build it locally, maybe it helps:

`elements/flatpak/sdk-arch-libs.bst`:
```yaml
kind: flatpak_image
depends:
- filename: flatpak/sdk-image.bst
  type: build

config:
  directory: '%{libdir}'
  exclude:
  - debug

  metadata:
    Runtime:
      name: org.gnome.Sdk.Compat.%{gcc_arch}
    ExtensionOf:
      ref: runtime/org.gnome.Sdk/%{gcc_arch}/%{branch}
```
`elements/flatpak/sdk-arch-libs-debug.bst`:
```yaml
kind: flatpak_image
depends:
- filename: flatpak/sdk-image.bst
  type: build

config:
  directory: '%{debugdir}%{libdir}'
  include:
  - debug

  metadata:
    Runtime:
      name: org.gnome.Sdk.Compat.%{gcc_arch}.Debug
    ExtensionOf:
      ref: runtime/org.gnome.Sdk/%{gcc_arch}/%{branch}
```

events.target_title: Provide Cube Root or arbitrary root function

note.body:
Unfortunately this uncovered another issue:

Problem: A cube with side length 5 has volume V. What is the side length of a cube that has volume 2V ?

So if we enter

`5³` = `125`

`125 × 2` = `250`

`₃√250` =  `6,299605249`    <------ Correct Answer

But if we enter the same thing as a single equation we get

`₃√2×5³` = `157,490131237`   <------ Wrong answer!

Maybe after entering the `√` operator we should print a [VINICULUM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vinculum_(symbol)) over the following characters until a space character is entered.

note.body:
I am still experiencing this if the machine is up for a very long time (after 2 days) without reboot.

It is on Gnome 3.28.2 on Fedora 28. After a fresh boot there is no freeze upon notifications.
I conjure that some of the .bashrc 'fixes' was because the user re-logged in after modifying .bashrc, and thus not observing this immediately. Eventually after a few days of up time it will come back.

The freeze is most evident and reproducible if the notification is triggered by Evolution's new email alert. When I produce a notification from gnome-terminal with either the terminal on the background and `sleep 3`, or with `notify-send hmmm`. There is no freeze.

I have two explanations : 

- the particular kind of notification Evolution sends choking up the gnome-shell main thread, (e.g. with special icon or kinds) or

- evolution hogging up CPU during the time it sends notifications; I recall Evolution does use multi-threaded message decoding and can be competing with gnome-shell.

Could we get some insights from a gnome-shell notification expert and an evolution expert?

events.target_title: Problem with 18.11rc on one computer

note.body:
Hi,

**TL;TR**

18.09b3 had a gschemas.compiled directly committed in ~/.local/share/gnome-shell/extensions/desktop-icons@csoriano/schemas (desktop-icons@csoriano is this extension) in newer versions `ninja -C .build install` created this file in ~/.local/schemas, where it wasn't found by the extension.

**Long answer**

Thanks for your answer, I could reproduce the problem even on my vm, I don't know why I didn't happen in first place, perhaps I didn't log out correctly and the extension didn't get reloaded. Anyhow I tried it with the brand new version 19.01, where I got the same issues.

When I clicked the gear icon next to the extension I got following error:
> GLib.FileError: Datei
> »~/.local/share/gnome-shell/extensions/desktop-icons@csoriano/schemas/gschemas.compiled«
> konnte nicht geöffnet werden: open() ist gescheitert: No such file or
> directory
> 
> Stack trace:
>   get_schema@~/.local/share/gnome-shell/extensions/desktop-icons@csoriano/prefs.js:87:24
>   init@~/.local/share/gnome-shell/extensions/desktop-icons@csoriano/prefs.js:73:16
>   _getExtensionPrefsModule@resource:///org/gnome/shell/extensionPrefs/main.js:68:9
>   wrapper@resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/_legacy.js:82:22
>   _selectExtension@resource:///org/gnome/shell/extensionPrefs/main.js:82:31
>   wrapper@resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/_legacy.js:82:22
>   _onCommandLine@resource:///org/gnome/shell/extensionPrefs/main.js:235:17
>   wrapper@resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/_legacy.js:82:22
>   main@resource:///org/gnome/shell/extensionPrefs/main.js:389:5
>   @<main>:1:43

*  So it searched a file called gschemas.compiled in  ~/.local/share/gnome-shell/extensions/desktop-icons@csoriano/schemas/
*  In 18.09b3 this file was directly checked into this git-repo and so it worked
* Starting with 18.11rc this file was missing, I had to do `meson --prefix=$HOME/.local/ .build` and `ninja -C .build install`. What I missed out here was that the gschemas.compiled got compiled and stored into ~/.local/schemas/gschemas.compiled and not into ~/.local/share/gnome-shell/extensions/desktop-icons@csoriano/schemas (~/.local/share/gnome-shell/extensions/desktop-icons@csoriano is actually the checked out git-repo of this extensions from where I executed this command). Ok I should have noticed `--prefix=$HOME/.local/`, but as said I'm quite inexperienced with gnome-shell.
* I moved from ~/.local/schemas/gschemas.compiled to ~/.local/share/gnome-shell/extensions/desktop-icons@csoriano/schemas/, did a logout and login of user and now it works.
* The repro 3 (with `export-zip.sh`) should have worked though, I haven't tried it in detail now, but the gschemas.compiled is packed in the right place within the zip.

**So it works for me now after some manual invention, but I'm still confused if `--prefix=$HOME/.local/` is correct for `meson`**

**Btw since this is a releaseversion now, are there any plans to package this for fedora 29 (I would even take a thirdparty repo or repos like copr) or is this the wrong place to ask for?**

Thanks for reading (and this extension in general)

Greetings!

events.target_title: Problem with 18.11rc on one computer

note.body: Short note: As I looked through the code 18.11rc seemed to have gschemas.compiled still committed, so I'm not quite sure where the problem was, since I tested with 19.01 today. Perhaps the gschemas.compiled got corrupt on my or your side and I didn't even notice that the correct file got compiled into ~/.local/schemas/gschemas.compiled with meson whereas the committed gschemas.compiled in this extension didn't work for me. Anyway 19.01 and the meson process (with the manual copying) worked for me

events.target_title: Problem with 18.11rc on one computer

note.body:
If I do `meson --prefix=$HOME/.local/ .build`, `ninja -C .build install` like stated in the README.md I get the gschemas.compiled directly into ~/.local, which doesn't work, if I do `/export-zip.sh` and then unzip the resulting `desktop-icons@csoriano.zip` in ~/.local/share/gnome-shell/extensions it works, cause gschemas.compiled is then in it's right place. I didn't expect to have to export and unzip on the same computer (just if developing on one computer and exporting to another computer).

It wasn't quite clear where to put gschemas.compiled by only reading README.md, perhaps a hint/clarification in README.md would make it clearer. Something like "Export extension ZIP file for extensions.gnome.org - must be executed on your local computer too", or you rename the caption "Export extension ZIP ..." to "Manual Installation of this extension". A location where to unpack the extension manually may be helpful for non-developers too.

Apart from this "path-problems" the plugin works, so it's more or less a "improve-README-request" now and not a real developer task and can then be closed.

note.body:
I would file a bug downstream. The GNOME developers are known to not support ancient versions anymore. And Xenial and it's software stack is pretty old by now. If the Ubuntu devs know about your issue the chances are that the update gets reverted.

Here is the Banshee Git history: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/banshee/commits/master As you can see the last sizeable code updates were from 2015. The rest are general code cleanups and translations. I wouldn't call it actively developed anymore.

events.target_title: [3.34] Weird numlock behaviour

note.body:
How sure are we that this is a Mutter issue?

@Keruspe, @pnowack  if I change to tty3, I see the same behaviour, Numlock is set to off even there and has to be toggled manually. Can it be another package? ibus related?

Please test this:
1) Boot your machine up
2) In GDM test the Numlock keys. For me they seem to work in the password field.
3) Don't log in to the graphical session but switch to the tty2 or tty3 terminal
4) After logging in on the terminal it doesn't work as expected and the bug is exposed. 

Thus I guess that Mutter isn't started up at all in this scenario and it cannot be a Mutter bug. Or am I wrong? And it isn't probably neither Wayland or X.org related at all.

But which other package (Ubuntu and at least Arch) can have regressed this?

Field to enter Password greyed out when creating new 7z archive
Field to enter Password greyed out when creating new 7z archive

note.body:
After further experimentation (namely, uninstalling, testing, reinstalling, and testing again), I've found that the password field becomes available after installing the package "p7zip-full" with apt (which provides the /usr/bin/7z executable, according to `dpkg -S /usr/bin/7z`). I suppose this solves the issue--I guess file-roller uses some sort of internal 7zip implementation if this package is not installed, and this internal implementation is not as feature-complete.

In fact, according to `apt-rdepends -s Suggests file-roller`, p7zip-full is in the list of packages "suggested" by the file-roller package:

`arj lha lzip lzma lzop ncompress p7zip-full rpm2cpio rzip sharutils sharutils-tools unace unalz unar xz-utils zoo`


I really only use file-roller for 7z, targz, and zip files, so, as far as I'm concerned, this can be closed. It may be worthwhile to add a note somewhere that extra functionality can be obtained by installing some of those recommended packages. Although I guess that's just always true of recommended packages.

note.body:
Sorry, I wasn't able to reproduce the issue for a while. Today I came upon a more reliable way to trigger the bug: - Get [tumblr-utils](https://github.com/bbolli/tumblr-utils). - Use `tumblr_backup.py` to download around 5,000 posts from a blog that is mainly images, with a command like `python2 tumblr_backup.py just-art`. - While the posts are downloading, use eog to open an image in the media subfolder of the blog backup. This may still take multiple attempts, but you are likely to trigger a different issue each time. With the patch, there are still crashes and warnings. I am not yet certain that it has no effect; the below testing was done without the patch. I don't think I noticed before, but sometimes the wrong image is opened. I got more information from a debug build, below. This is with EOG version 3.33.1, commit 2c821728. All of these are separate issues. Sometimes only one of the following occurs, and sometimes it is a combination of them. I'm pretty sure they all occur on Thread 1 (eog), though you may want to check the messages against the backtraces.
1. A GTK assertion failure, followed by a SIGABRT. No support for tabs/tabbed browsing combined with meta-search across open PDFs

note.body:
I'm totally with this! The only reason why I can't use Evince is because it doesn't have tabs. I generally open multiple PDFs and having a handful of windows is just annoying. I really would love to use it as my default PDF viewer but it just needs tab support! qpdfview is my PDF viewer of choice since it has tabs.

Like OP has said, Nautilus, gnome-terminal and other GNOME programs have tab support, why can't Evince also have it? I understand that it might require a lot of work but the developers haven't said anything about this. What kind of work is expected to implement tabbed functionality?

Looking forward to hearing from the Evince folks.

events.target_title: No support for tabs/tabbed browsing combined with meta-search across open PDFs

note.body:
Any word on tabbed support for Evince @gpoo? It has been a while but I cannot find any technical reasons why this request has been dismissed for so long. Any information would be greatly appreciated!


**EDIT:**

Okay, so after doing some research, Evince developers have made it clear that they aren't going to support tabs. 

Here is a related issue: GNOME/evince#182 - This is what the maintainer last said:

>  I already said why: the actual concept of Evince is one document, one window.

> Perhaps you can point us to usability studies that show that having this concept is a usability deficiency. Otherwise, it is just another user opinion (which any user is entitled to have).

The thing that bugs me is that what is the purpose of having "one document, one window"? Does it help with productivity or usability? I understand that software development has a scope and constraints but this feature has been requested by many - [scopes can change too :)](https://www.quickbase.com/blog/tactics-for-dealing-with-scope-change-on-a-project).

Regards

events.target_title: Choosing default install directory?

note.body:
@gokigen @lyamc There is actually a way to do this! All you have to do is create a symbolic link and it works as you'd expect! I have another drive with tons of space and I want the VMs to be there. The following commands from [here](https://fedoramagazine.org/getting-started-with-virtualization-in-gnome-boxes/) did the trick:

>  Tip: If you would like to store your Gnome Boxes disks (which can get large) elsewhere, such as on a storage hard drive, you can use a symbolic link to move its location.  Create a symbolic link from

` ~/.local/share/gnome-boxes`

> To your desired location:

`$ rm -rf ~/.local/share/gnome-boxes && ln -s /path/to/drive ~/.local/share/gnome-boxes`

Source: https://fedoramagazine.org/getting-started-with-virtualization-in-gnome-boxes/

I would still like a GUI way of doing this but it works.

note.body:
The latest Distros will not let a person use a "deb" package install. I came across this problem with
the Debian "Buster", LMDE 3 Cinnamon and the Ubuntu 18.10. The "Gnome-Commander" is also not listed in
their repositories. I suspect it is a reason for security? I use Gnome-Commander as a "Adm" and never
use it as a "Standard User" since it is limited. I wrote a "python" script to execute the program as
a "Adm" and it is the "BEST!" program to use for file and application use for administrators. The 
current Distributions of Linux will be driving users away from Linux because of a "Ghost" chase that
is probably initiated by MS. I've been using the Linux distributions for over 10 years and the reason
I switched to Linux was because of security and problems with it with the MS products. The product that
was developed for Debian 9.5 is impossible to beat for "Adm" users. I doubt that I will update to the
newer Distributions of Linux until these versions are "bug" free. A few months ago I disabled updates
for Linux Mint "Cinnamon" since it was breaking the applications and the program. Now, LMDE 3 has the
"Snapshot" application shipped with the Distribution to replace a malformed update that gets into the
repository. I am assuming that maybe, the developers are using their users as "Beta" testers and not
informing them? The Ubuntu Group is way ahead, they inform their users that their distributions are
in "alfa" or 'beta" stage and then list the distributions as "LTS." I went to Debian after the Linux
debacle which they repeated over 7 years ago with I suspect applications getting mixed into the Linux
and Ubuntu repository. I left using Linux and started using PuppyLinux which was far for stable at the
time versus the Linux versions. It's a "round-robin" situation, maybe a Unix or DOS system was the most
reliable versus the graphical interface that isn't secure?

I ran the Windows compatibility program and started GIMP again and up popped a GIMP Crash Debug Window with the following report:

note.body: Thanks, the warnings disappeared. Let me know if you need more testing from my part about the main issue.

events.target_title: during debug stepping over switches to another thread

note.body:
I studied a bit the issue. Apparently after the -exec-next command, gdb writes the out of band message =thread-selected with the id of the last of my threads, thus the plugin catches the thread switching. when the *stopped reply is parsed, the thread id in the reply is read but not used to switch back to the thread the breakpoint is in.

I'm sending you a diff file with the mods for a possible solution. I used the thread id of the *stopped response to switch to the correct thread, but another possible solution could be to ignore the =thread-selected message.

While studying this code, I noticed also that the plugin uses the thread-select messages which apparently are now deprecated from gdb/mi. I tried to modify this aspect just for -stack-list-locals to see if the recommended approach could work, so you'll find this change in the same diff.

Another thing I noticed while browsing through the log is that after a breakpoint is hit gdb sends a message complaining about not finding a file... this I can't figure out why it happens. For an example see line 1217 of the attached log file.

[mod.patch](/uploads/1776e1e0d923321ef39aeda47e301703/mod.patch)

[log.log](/uploads/d12405db3b666f7399692d0bd5229ab6/log.log)

events.target_title: during debug stepping over switches to another thread

note.body:
Hi Christian, unfortunately I sent you the wrong diff file for the part regarding the -stack-list-locals improvements. In fact, the commit a3d3bc6e broke the locals list. I'm sending a new patch file which corrects this issue I created.

Also, I'd like to modify the gdb code further to remove some commands that are deprecated and unifying the code for parsing locals and arguments. If you're ok with this I'll make a merge request.

[fix_locals.diff](/uploads/ed4826d79314beafc59492a7b117aa1f/fix_locals.diff)

events.target_title: g_spawn_*() is extremely slow under certain circumstances
g_spawn_*() is extremely slow under certain circumstances

note.body:
`g_spawn_*()` has seen optimizations for Solaris in the past
([1](https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=357585),
[2](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/commit/af475972c6e57ffbf436d5d93d1d33239dccde5f))
using [`fdwalk(3C)`].  Unfortunately that only seems to exists on
Solaris.  However the manual page also mentions the related
[`closefrom(2)`] which also exists on the BSDs.

Currently the file descriptors are dealt with in the following way
(ignoring certain conditionals):

1. fork
1. set [`FD_CLOEXEC`] on all FDs >= 3 using [`fdwalk(3C)`] or an appropriate replacement
1. set up `std*_fd`
1. exec

I suggest changing the file descriptor handling to this instead:

1. fork
1. set up `std*_fd`
1. close all FDs >= 3 using [`closefrom(2)`] or an appropriate replacement
1. exec

This will essentially replace a large number of [`fcntl(2)`] syscalls
with a single [`closefrom(2)`] syscall on some platforms.  Platforms
without [`closefrom(2)`] aren't off any worse.  If it isn't already
present on a platform it can be easily implemented in terms of the
already existing [`fdwalk()`] replacement function, as illumos' manual
page of [`fdwalk(3C)`] shows.

Another advantage of dealing with the open file descriptors in terms
of [`closefrom(2)`] is that it can be more easily and efficiently
implemented by other platform specific functions such as AIX' and
NetBSD's [`fcntl(?,F_CLOSEM)`].

Directly closing all file descriptors instead of marking them to be
closed on exec should also be okay, since that action is performed in
the (grand)child, which doesn't otherwise do anything else with the
file descriptors.  I am not familiar with the internals of GLib but I
think this should work.

I have a relatively small patch for this change, which I need to give
some more testing.  But do you agree with this change in principle?

[`fdwalk(3C)`]: https://illumos.org/man/3c/fdwalk
[`closefrom(2)`]: https://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=closefrom
[`FD_CLOEXEC`]: http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/basedefs/fcntl.h.html
[`fcntl(2)`]: http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/functions/fcntl.html
[`fdwalk()`]: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/blob/245279e834cfcde0e07445a879748d08d5e5633b/glib/gspawn.c#L1171
[`fcntl(?,F_CLOSEM)`]: https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/en/ssw_aix_71/com.ibm.aix.basetrf1/fcntl.htm

events.target_title: g_spawn_*() is extremely slow under certain circumstances

note.body:
> The only real argument I can see against using `closefrom()` (...)
> is that it means you can’t use the `GSpawnChildSetupFunc` to un-set
> `O_CLOEXEC` on an FD (...)  I could imagine that some enterprising
> applications are abusing `GSpawnChildSetupFunc`s like that.

Yes, I was wondering if users would be relying on GLib internals when
using `GSpawnChildSetupFunc`.  I didn't know about [Debian Code
Search].  I'll have a look at the real word use of `g_sync_*()` there.
Thanks.

> Another alternative, which I would also be happy with (...) is to
> use FreeBSD’s `kinfo_getfile()` (...) The downside is that it’s
> (probably?) FreeBSD-only.

Yes, `kinfo_getfile()` is only available on FreeBSD whereas
`closefrom()` is available on all BSDs and Solaris derivatives.
Another problem with `kinfo_getfile()` is that for it to work the
target process must be [debuggable].  Some sysctls and the [MAC
framework] have a say in this.  It's fine for a debugger to rely on
this, but a regular program might not even be able to use it and
therefore not profit from the optimization.

Setting the sysctl `security.bsd.unprivileged_proc_debug` is exposed
as an [hardening option] in FreeBSD's installer.  It also has been
mentioned as a workaround in a few security errata notices and is
often listed in security hardening guides for FreeBSD.  So I would
assume that not an insignifican number of users have it set and
thereby have prevented `kinfo_getfile()` from working.

[Debian Code Search]: https://codesearch.debian.net/
[debuggable]: https://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=p_candebug
[MAC framework]: https://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=mac&sektion=9
[hardening option]: https://reviews.freebsd.org/D6826

events.target_title: g_spawn_*() is extremely slow under certain circumstances

note.body:
> Given that Christian says that VTE is explicitly using
> `GSpawnChildSetupFunc` in this way, I think we can’t use
> `closefrom()`.

The way I understood it is that VTE uses its own [customized copy] of
the functions instead of calling `g_spawn_*()` from GLib:

> (However, note that VTE contains a slightly modified copy of
> gspawn.c and g-t uses that instead of glib's g_spawn*().)

Grepping through gnome-terminal's and VTE's source code confirms that
the only function called there from [`glib/gspawn.c`] is
[`gspawn_close_pid()`].

> > Another problem with `kinfo_getfile()` is that for it to work the
> > target process must be [debuggable].
>
> Even when a process is querying its own file information?

Yes, even then `kinfo_getfile()` can be denied.

> Could it be changed in FreeBSD so that’s allowed when the target
> process is the current process.

There doesn't seem to be a configurable option for it.  So FreeBSD's
kernel would have to be patched.  But that is outside of my expertise.

> Unless you have any other ideas, (...)

Maybe one could use [`/dev/fd`] similarly to how Linux'
[`/proc/self/fd`] is used in [`fdwalk()`].  However that file system
is not enabled by default.  It's also no longer present on OpenBSD.

I still prefer the `closefrom()` solution.  It works over a wider
range of operating systems and configurations.  But I still have to
check that this breaks none of the existing consumers of GLib.

[customized copy]: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/vte/blob/5a01bf95904148a06baf7f908f7321ff3fc7d1a8/src/vtespawn.cc
[`glib/gspawn.c`]: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/blob/33158c86c102eccb197bd60918ce1ecebc62ac3f/glib/gspawn.c
[`gspawn_close_pid()`]:  https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/vte/blob/5a01bf95904148a06baf7f908f7321ff3fc7d1a8/src/reaper.cc#L54
[debuggable]: https://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=p_candebug
[`/dev/fd`]: https://www.freebsd.org/cgi/man.cgi?query=fdescfs
[`/proc/self/fd`]: http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man5/proc.5.html
[`fdwalk()`]: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/blob/33158c86c102eccb197bd60918ce1ecebc62ac3f/glib/gspawn.c#L1183

note.body:
I have just updated from 2.8.22 to 2.10.8 on Windows 10, and I am seeing this message for nearly every XCF file on my PC (I've tested at least a dozen files).

Looking through examples, it doesn't seem to show for any files created before November 2012; I suspect this corresponds to when I first installed a 2.8.x version of GIMP (I think 2.8.2 would have been current at the time). If there's an easy way of confirming the version which created each file, let me know.

[Attached example](/uploads/8583429c60f7f591c33f86dbb0fdfb18/now_leaving_sunnydale.xcf) is the smallest XCF file I happen to have which exhibits the problem.

Note that GIMP does *not* complain about XMP data when opening the JPEGs from my camera which are the main source for most of these files.
